description: From Middle English disjoynen, from Old French desjoindre (“disjoin”), from Latin disiungō, from dis- + iungō (“join”).

adjectives.description: disjoint (comparative more disjoint, superlative most disjoint)

entries.meaning: (set theory, not comparable) Of two or more sets, having no members in common; having an intersection equal to the empty set.

verbs.description: disjoint (third-person singular simple present disjoints, present participle disjointing, simple past and past participle disjointed)

entries.meaning: To render disjoint; to remove a connection, linkage, or intersection.
examples: to disjoint limbs; to disjoint bones; to disjoint poultry by carving

entries.meaning: To break the natural order and relations of; to make incoherent.
